Comment: Governor Walker occupies what has been described as the most powerful state executive position in the Country.  It was designed that way and now that power comes into play. Governor Walker doesn't need to "veto" the entire budget because , according to the State Constitution, : "He may, by veto, strike or reduce items in appropriation bills."  While the legislature might have come up with the 3/4 vote to access the CBR they will never come up with the 3/4 vote to override the various vetoes of appropriations.  The clock is approaching "high noon" on the streets of Juneau.

Comment: Well, to answer my own question, there is this link:  http://palaeos.com/cenozoic/pliocene/pliocene.htm 
... and this one:  https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2003SC/finalprogram/abstract_48794.htm

It appears that there are many documented species of marine molluscs going extinct toward the end of the Pliocene, in some places a turnover rate > 2/3 of extant species.  However, at least one author notes that *total diversity* actually remained fairly constant (i.e., new species popped up).  Gastropods (snails) suffered more than bivalves (clams and oysters).   Nowhere do I see the suggestion that higher CO2 levels were to blame - instead, cooling ocean temperatures due to the onset of glaciation, or nutrient reduction due to shifts in oceanic circulation are called up as triggers of extinction.

Comment: Jeff,

There is no point in Canada opening these discussions in a bellicose fashion (and many reasons why to do so would be counterproductive).

I believe that you are mistaking as weakness Canada's opening attempt to frame these difficult negotiations in positive terms.  I read Canada's opening steps as a wise attempt to marshal foreign and US domestic support and generally to gauge the field of battle.  In this way, Canada will be best placed to counterpunch if necessary (and, importantly, avoid initiating disputes that the US doesn't intend to initiate and keep the talks productive insofar as the US is prepared to do likewise).

Canada is on firmer ground than your comment implies and we shouldn't psych ourselves out before negotiations are seriously begun.

Comment: Tom, I work in the schools: Memorizing? They haven't had students memorize anything in decades. Now teachers use project-based learning, group work, self-directed inquiry-these have been the norm for a long time. Your idea of an oppressive teacher demanding students memorize things just isn't reality. No one is teaching to any test regardless of what you hear. The tests themselves aren't even the kinds of tests a teacher could teach to if they wanted. Most of them test for abstract skills, which really just test the kids' intelligence, which is actually more unfair than testing for a body of knowledge. "Active" learning is one of the many canards in progressive education. Reading is an active process, and so is taking notes while listening to a teacher lecture. It is the mind that is active or not.  John Dewey would turn over in his grave if he saw what liberals had done to his philosophy of education.

Comment: I believe most attorneys will tell you that litigation is a last resort: it's the step you take when an agreement seems impossible.  One of my professors used to tell us that when you see a case go to trial, it usually means the attorneys failed.  While I think that statement may be a bit over the top, it does carry a lot of truth.  

The point of my post was really just to take umbrage with this emerging language from the bishops that seems to want to rewrite history, and to position the church's leadership as being a leader and a model for the rest of the world when it comes to the handling of abuse.  As I see it, they have a VERY long way to go before they can claim that mantle.  I also suspect this is not an accident:  this theme is emerging   simultaneously in more and more statements by bishops worldwide: the bishops want to rewrite history. I find this rather disturbing.

Comment: I personally think the focus in Washington is wrong.  While the convoluted mess of regulations that is the ACA needs fixing this year, certainly, the cost of healthcare needs to be analyzed and reworked.  Not through 70's era or post-WWII price controls (which helped create the mess we're in now) but honest study of the components of healthcare costs and agreement on reforms.  By that I mean, for example, that we don't say pharma can't charge more than $5 a capsule or something, but maybe we develop a matrix of allowable costs and a review of price increases, so we don't have another Epipen episode with prices quadrupled for a drug that hasn't changed, and for which there are no development costs left to cover.  

Insurance reform will continue to be a matter of paper and numbers shuffling until cost analysis and reform is carried out.  Just as college costs will continue to be a matter of paper and numbers shuffling until administrators are forced to explain and justify their costs.

Comment: The emotional labour reference warrants further exploration.

It is usually only backwards communist systems that measure value by input, rather than output.

For most traditional forms of labour, we have a range of rates that translate labour input into a differentiated range of output values.  

Emotional labour only rarely warrants such measurement - for example, there's no objective price put on remembering birthdays or visiting the recently widowed.

Maybe we need something like a price mechanism to differentiate wasted emotional labour from valuable emotional labour?  Without that price, we're going to find grievances being accumulated on the basis of something that may not be worth what the labourer wants to get credit for.

Comment: Great article Sol, well said!  

I have bootstrapped everything I've done thus far as well, but my approach hasn't been to just come out of pocket alone.  Instead, I have entered numerous startup competitions, and have won a number of them.  This has had multiple benefits:
1.  I received funding I needed to take another step forward, without having to give up any equity in the business, and,
2.  It helps to validate the business opportunity.  Yes, one can win a competition with a bad product that won't make it in the market, however, when you start winning more than one, it absolutely has to help validate your idea.  My wins have come from both Audience votes and Judges votes.  

Thank you for sharing your insight. Perhaps my minor comments will also help someone else find another way to boostrap like I have. 

Keep up the great work - 

Steve

Comment: Actually, that is not the primary reason why Symantec came here.   They had expanded a lot by acquiring different companies, and that left them with duplicate service and support groups scattered all across the country for their different product lines.   They wanted to get rid of all of this redundancy and improve efficiency, so they decided to consolidate all of their service and support operations in one location.

Symantec did a nation-wide search on where would be the best spot.   The finalists were Austin, TX,   Boulder, CO, and here.

Symantec does own those huge buildings they built in Springfield.   I would be surprised if they moved out entirely.  Although I think that their property tax exemption extension may have ended.   Which would mean that they are now having to pay property taxes.   The tax exemption also required that they maintain a level of employees, in order to qualify for it.   So if that has ended, then there would be no tax drawback to downsizing.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: Teacher aides in special education classrooms need to be properly trained in how students with various disabilities respond to specific stimuli and how to deal with students who are off task. As I originally suggested, the aide involved needs more training...both in the understanding of autistic behavior and how to respond to it. I did not say she was a bad person, just someone who needs more training. If she did not get that training she ought to be complaining to the district and her union. Disabled students do not bear the responsibility for the classroom environment, as well as the responsibility to ensure that federal law is being followed. Ultimately, it is the ASD that bears that responsibility. For those who are interested and have a whole lot of time, the relevant law is called the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. It is very long, but is the primary governing document for US schools when it comes to dealing with disabled students.

Comment: Reverting to second class will not change the structure of City government. It will still be the same Council-Manager government with the same City staff in the same positions.

Reverting to second class will not cause an election of a new City Council, despite what many people were told.  Under our WA Constitution, the people can only remove council members by recall, and this is not a recall vote.  So ultimately the State will not permit an election, because there will be no vacancies to fill.  So in January, the candidates elected this November will be seated with the remaining incumbents to serve out their full terms.

Reverting to second class will suspend the citizens' right to initiative and referendum. WA law only permits second class cities to hold advisory votes.  That is unquestionably a huge loss to the people.

I've been asking for a year, and I ask again: what are the *benefits* to the people?  What do you think you will change for the better?

Comment: I'm just ending (or perhaps temporarily suspending, we shall see) a month-long break from social media, including this site. Part of what I'm wrestling with is the polarization that makes worthwhile dialogue between people of goodwill so much harder than it used to be.

I wish I could say it's getting better, but I don't see much evidence of that, and this site is symptomatic. There is so much anger here, so much vitriol. It is wearying. I've never been squeamish about snark, God knows, but where that used to come in the course of conversation, now it seems to be so many posters' default mode. The gloves are off right from the get-go.

I get that much of this has to do with the strong feelings people have about the Trump presidency, but the thought that keeps coming to me is that I don't want every conversation I'm involved in over the next four years to be driven by what's going on in Washington. Life is more than that, so much more.

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

Comment: yarr mcfleur,

This is an essay on the danger of normalization.  I thought that Ms. Balkissoon cleverly jumped from one example of normalization to another to show how frightening the human characteristic of normalization is.  She uses the normalization of pedestrian and baby deaths as an analogy to the normalization of some politics occurring south of the border.

Humans naturally become less alarmed by common occurrences and that can be dangerous.   For instance, we are less afraid of driving (where per capita deaths are high) then we are of of bear and shark attacks (where per capita deaths are low).  The idea that I think that Ms. Balkissoon was trying to present, is that if we can become numbed to babies being run over by cars, we can also become numbed to issues such as allowing ourselves to sugarcoat a presidential lie.

I don't think it's fair for you to call her analogies a "fiasco."  It would be more fair say to say that you don't understand them or you don't agree with them.

Comment: The other half of this article is the question of whether controlled-release really works for most patients and whether drugs like Oxycontin are really an improvement over morphine for pain management. The pattern of 12-hour larger doses instead of 4-hour smaller doses was heavily pushed to doctors by Purdue, despite mounting evidence that the drug couldn't control severe pain for that long and patients were increasing their use to compensate (which meant more sales).

http://www.latimes.com/projects/oxycontin-part1/

The modern history of opiates is one "less addictive!" claim after another, all equally false. It's potentially addictive because of the way it works, but most people who use opiates at some point don't become addicted because the drug effect interferes with the positive things in their life. If your life feels empty and hopeless, opiates are just one way you could fall down.

Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: I was trained to be an altar server prior to Vatican II and was required to memorize various Latin prayer responses at a very early age.

During the Offertory when the congregation responds to the priest's "Brethren, pray that my Sacrifice and yours may be acceptable to God the Father Almighty." with "May the Lord receive the Sacrifice from thy hands, to the praise and glory of His Name, to our benefit and that of all His holy Church."  I silently pray "Suscipiat Dominus sacrificium de manibus tuis ad laudem, et gloriam nominis sui, ad utilitatem quoque nostram, totiusque Ecclesiae suae sanctae.", drawn from the deep reaches of my childhood memories.  

I love the Mass in the vernacular because it allows the community to worship God as one.  However, I also cherish my little private "Latin moment" because it touches a spiritual chord deep within me that spans a lifetime.

Comment: Go to fiscal.wa.gov. Select Operating Budget top-left
Select "Agency Detail". Takes a moment to load choices.
"Agency" drop-down select "Early Learning", another moment to load.
Select "View Report" (button on the right).
When reviewing these you always need watch for whether biennial or one year at a time. This is where you begin (it's 3 pages).
They're also in the "Summary Comparison", in "Other Education", which you see by expanding the section, the "+" sign.
DoEL has a workforce of ~326 (290.7 FTE), which you find in a spreadsheet of names, titles and wages over 4 years. Download it (floppy drive icon) for analysis.

Comment: Thank you, Doug Saunders, for this very insightful piece! I always enjoy your articles, but this one hit me personally. I grew up in England and came to Canada in 1971. I chose Canada because it was easier to get into than the U.S. and because I spoke French and found Quebec interesting. 

In my early years in Canada, I thought of moving to the U.S., but I've come to appreciate Canada as an incredibly diverse country, free from the hangups of having to be "great" or powerful, yet making huge strides in social progress in a relatively quiet and peaceful way. You beautifully summarized, and gave historical context to, most of the reasons I find Canada a very exciting place to be.

A fitting start to 2017!

Comment: Let's get one thing straight! It is not double dipping to work in the public and private health care systems. It is double dipping if a health care provider bills for the same procedure or part of a procedure in both systems. Speaking as a surgeon, I can state unequivocally that our federal/provincial politicians have failed Canadians miserably in managing and funding our health care system. I will gladly operate more than one day per week.  I am only allotted one OR day per week. There is no money for more staff and in-patient beds are insufficient in number to allow patients who must be admitted postoperatively to be treated in a timely manner.  There are many young medical specialists graduating from residencies who will not be able to find work in Canada. The Canadian taxpayer paid to educate these medical specialists but will be unable obtain a satisfactory return on their investment. Face it, health care in Canada is rationed. Politicians who deny this are lying to Canadians.

Comment: Well then, you would seem exceptionally qualified to join the adjunct pool at UAA. I look forward to seeing "R. Homeroid" listed as the instructor of a class soon.
As for your suggestions to students, it is obvious that you and I have had very different experiences in higher ed.  I will offer my own survival tips to Alaskan students (applicable to all institutions):
1. Select the classes that fit best into your schedule. Time/energy management is going to be crutial. Schedule 2 hours out of class for every credit you take (more if your academic skills are a bit rusty).
2. If you are having trouble connecting the concepts to practice, try a Google search. There is a reason you are required to learn this stuff. Every topic may not be relevent to what you ultimately do, but there is a connection (not always obvious) to the careers associated with your degree.
3. Own your performance. Don't blame others if you come up short. Examine what you could have done better and then get it done.

Comment: This highlights what has become almost epidemic in our society - trial by social media. People posting snippets of video or pictures to show how they have been offended, or hold the moral high card. Another recent incident was with a teacher in WV who was accused of demeaning a student with autism. Without knowing any background or any reporter doing any investigation, the video went viral internationally, picked up by many news organizations and talk shows. The teacher has received death threats, the school went on lockdown. The back story tells a different story, and shows a much clearer picture of the truth. 

So while you may be thinking that you are going to combat "injustice", take a moral stance, or even impress your friends, you could be destroying someone's life, without even understanding the bigger picture. I hope our culture can begin to turn this around. Sadly I think we have already crossed the point of no return.

Comment: There is a difference in approaches.  The Libertarian Party has pushed for a bill that would eliminate the existing laws without creating some new bureau of marijuana with lots of complicated regulations, licensing requirements,  and fees.  The laws would then only address doing things like distributing it to children, driving under the influence, trespassing on someone else's property to grow, etc. If you got into selling you'd pay GET like anyone else. There'd be no special tax.  Anyone could grow it.  

Many other reformers favor a tightly regulated legal crop that makes money for the state, while continuing to criminalize ordinary folks who want to participate.  We don't think this is fair or appropriate.
Tracy Ryan
Chair, The Libertarian Party of Hawaii.

Comment: On the basis of yield alone, the chance of this being a fusion ("H") bomb is very low.  In theory, they could've boosted a fission bomb by adding deuterium/tritium to the hollow core to test as a proof of design concept.  That would give a modest increase in yield, but a "real" fusion bomb has its hydrogen surrounding the fission bomb, which allows for much higher yields.

At 50kt. this NK device isn't even a particularly big fission bomb.

There is a "soft" upper limit to fission bombs.  Ivy King, the largest pure-fission bomb ever exploded by the US, was ~500kt or ten times the estimated yield of NK's latest.  So, obviously, there's plenty of headroom for theirs to be a pure-fission device.  Without further evidence, it's logical to conclude that's exactly what it was.

Even if this was a true fusion bomb, the notion that their first one is ICBM-capable is ludicrous.  Our own first H-bomb (Ivy Mike) weighed 82 tons and was the size of a small building.  NK is just woofin'.

Comment: The real reason Mexico continues to support Mexicans in the United States is quite simple. They receive more money from them than they do from their own oil industry.

“Feb 2, 2016 MEXICO CITY – The central bank reported Tuesday that money sent home by Mexicans overseas hit nearly $24.8 billion last year, overtaking oil revenues for the first time as a source of foreign income.

Remittances were up 4.75 percent from 2014 when they totaled $23.6 billion, the Bank of Mexico said. They had never before surpassed petroleum since the Bank of Mexico began tracking them in 1995.

Analysts pointed to slumping global prices for oil, which earned Mexico $23.4 billion in 2015, and improved economic conditions in the United States, home to more than 11 million Mexicans and the source of nearly all Mexico’s remittances.”

Comment: Dog yards/teams are made up of a solid 12-100 ( or more) dogs yet only around 18 run in the Iditarod, unless a far and few between puppy team runs.. So what does everyone think happens to those countless other dogs and what happens to the elite ones no longer used for racing? Mushing is a very costly endeavor with 90% ownership who would NOT consider themselves wealthy by any means. There are some great and truly committed mushers who care for their dogs for a life time. I have been fortunate to have know a few. However, too many competitive and recreational mushers view these pets as objects to fulfill short term dreams and  goals without taking on the life expectancy of the dogs into account. While some of these dogs find great homes,  too many end up in unwanted ones and are abused because they were not raised as pets/indoor dogs or end up shelters where they are euthanized.

Comment: "restricts snow accumulation" how?  Unless you heat it, it's not gonna melt any faster, which means accumulation.  You seem to be suggesting a zig-zag pattern of toughs/valleys, which (1) I don't see how that would make it melt any faster over a wide area, and (2) even if it did, would be accomplished a helluva lot cheaper with simple materials instead of very expensive solar panels.  (We'd also already be seeing it done if troughs worked to eliminate snow load, which seems doubtful.)

Short of heat-melting, still seems like it's gonna be the weight of the snow (which you always have to build to support) PLUS the very heavy planter boxes/soil/trees/etc (adding a lot of expense). Alternately, solar panels may not weight enough to require a more expensive roof, but the panels themselves are very expensive, thus adding a lot of cost.

No matter how you slice it, this is sure to add significant cost.

Comment: The underlying problem is political and campaign spending in general. All parties are obsessed with raising money in the current system, and focusing on one 'unseemly practice' will simply mean that parties will look for new ones. 

The way to address it is to limit the amounts that can be spent, and to return to a certain level of public funding. The $2 per vote subsidy is one measure that should be reinstated. 

If we limit the amount of  spending, and  provide a certain proportion of it through public financing, a lot of this ongoing problem will disappear. An even greater benefit is that it could temper the hyper-partisanship that parties feel obliged to use in their fund-raising appeals (anything to get that supporter to click on the 'Donate' button....), and help return our democracy to a more civil state. One only has to look south to see how the insane role of money corrupts both political parties and the ideal of civil discourse.

Comment: I'm surprised Haycox doesn't specifically mention the most pressing reason for the Greenland and Svalbard weather outposts: American convoys to Murmansk, critical to the Russian war effort.  The Germans menaced those convoys by air and sea.  Weather prediction was obviously critical to their success.  This was the reason for an extraordinarily risky mission undertaken by Norwegian resistance: to land a commando team in northern Norway to sabotage German  coastal weather and air control stations.  The mission was betrayed to the Germans by a Norwegian civilian and only one commando escaped, Jan Baalsrud, whose incredible story is told in one of the best books to come out of World War II, We Die Alone, by David Howarth.  If you haven't read it, you don't fully understand what kind of heroism people are capable of.

Comment: "As a combined result of the price drop and new pipelines built to service oil fields in North Dakota, CAPP's forecast demand for pipeline capacity out of Western Canada was estimated in June at less than five million barrels a day by 2030"

This statement by Professor Leach assumes the only reasons for reduced forecasts of western Canadian crude production were economic, and is thus false or at least incomplete. The open-ended nature and length of the regulatory process, and the opposition from both BC and eastern Canada to pipeline projects, has been a significant factor in stifling large capital projects which would expand western Canadian crude production.

At $US50/WTIbbl there is for the mature operators in the oil sands, at least a $20/bbl (CDN) operating margin (67%), even given the discount for Western Canadian Select. I don't think it's the current price of oil that's repressing investment in crude production in Canada, it's the capricious nature of the regulatory process.

Comment: Until convicted in a fair and just trial, he is not a "proven" terrorist. And how fair and just is a trial that relies on evidence extracted with torture? In WW2 the US relied on interrogation of captured German soldiers conducted by recent immigrants and refugees from Germany. Generally,  a cigarette, shared family photos, and empathy were all it took. Trickery was sometimes used, such as setting up a tent staffed with a supposed Soviet intelligence officer. Since the Germans were petrified of being turned over to the Russians, the casual threat that they had been flagged to be turned over for some reason was all it took. Torture was never used. And when the Bush regime resorted to torture the association of these specialized veterans objected. Its likely that the question of whether evidence tainted by torture can be used will eventually reach the Supreme Court. If the Court follows long standing US and international law, it will say no.

Comment: The economic damage is negligible when we're energy-independent, producing our own fossil fuels rather than having to import them.  We spend over $300 billion/yr on oil.  When most of that was to OPEC countries, that money left our economy.  When we spend the same amount on domestically produced oil, it stays in our economy.  The environmental impact has been grossly exaggerated.  The CO2 emissions improve the environment; it is not a pollutant.

The pollutant from coal-fired power plants was SO2, a highly reactive emission that quickly combined with particulates in the air to form "brown clouds."  Clean coal technology eliminates nearly all of that.  Again, the CO2 it emits isn't a pollutant.

About 60% of our electricity in Colorado still comes from coal-fired plants.  Where's the pollution?  Our cost of electricity is among the lowest in the nation, and the nation's is one third of Germany's, where they rely more on solar and wind than we do.

Comment: To answer your own question: Yes, the entire premise/justification of providing a bike share program is that it is going to make the community better as a whole. Studies may show this, or more likely, reliable studies are yet to come, as bike share programs are somewhat experimental still. Currently we have an exceedingly expensive tax funded transportation program (public streets and private vehicles), with very little tax support for less expensive options for people. Pedestrian orientated community planning, bike share and bike support intitiatves, and better transit services, can all reduce the exorbitant economic drag of the tax-payer supported system of extremely large and costly road infrastructure and the extremely high cost of the private automobiles that must be paired with roads in order for this particular transportation system to work. The question is: are bike share programs an efficient (or more efficient) use of transportation dollars. We probably don't know yet.

a small bomb made of a metal or wooden box filled with powder, used to blast down a door or to make a hole in a wall.

• a kind of firework that explodes with a sharp report.

PHRASES

hoist with (or by) one's own petard

have one's plans to cause trouble for others backfire on one.[from Shakespeare's Hamlet ( iii. iv. 207); hoist is in the sense ‘lifted and removed,’ past participle of dialect hoise (see hoist) .]

ORIGIN

mid 16th cent.: from French pétard, from péter ‘break wind.’

Comment: This reporter needs to look more closely at history.  The 1980 Alaska Lands Act did not make the coastal plain of the Arctic Refuge "available for drilling."  This landmark act mandated a 5-year study to assess the biological values and the impacts from possible oil and gas development on the coastal plain. Seismic exploration was authorized to determine resource values but any drilling was prohibited without a future act of Congress.  The coastal plain is the most sensitive biological area of the entire refuge, as the report to Congress well describes.  Oil drilling brings major impacts and is not compatible with the purposes of this wildlife refuge.  Congress would have to circumvent current law to drill in the Arctic Refuge.  To think that the State of Alaska is pushing to invade a unique and magnificent wildlife refuge that belongs to all Americans, when the National Petroleum Reserve and adjacent state lands offer clear development opportunities, is just pure greed.

Comment: On this day, Martin Luther King Jr. day, I have been thinking more since the article was published that was about my parents Mr and Mrs Robert and Beatrice Coleman's efforts. They both came from humble beginnings. My mother was born on the reservation in Idaho and her family moved to Eastern Washington as farm workers.  My dad came from Louisiana from a family who was sharecroppers. How they came to met in Seattle and went north to Alaska is another story. My sister and I grew up in Fairbanks not knowing that our parents were "activists" as we were told that it is the right thing to do when there is wrong being done.  As ordinary everyday people, they gave us this beautiful legacy to carry forward and it has been at the core of my work because it is the right thing to do when there is inequity and injustice happening. I am so grateful.

Comment: "You do know that he was a decorated member of the colonial army before becoming a turncoat, right?" Um, yes.

The analogy ends there. The US government made a conscious decision to give amnesty & pardon those who fought for the south. Lee effectively ended the war by surrendering and kept it from restarting 2 years later by talking down those southerners who wanted to. He supported Johnson's plan for Reconstruction & became a symbol that aided its success. He was a productive, loyal member of American society the rest of his life.  He was neither pro-secession nor vehemently pro-slavery. He was a complex man (supported black education but not the right to vote); a product of his time. 

Where Arnold was ticked off at America & out for revenge, Lee fought the Union out of loyalty to his state, which democratically voted to secede. When he had the chance to bring the war to a close, he took it. Yes, he fought against his former country. But simplistic analysis of this man is impossible.

Comment: Perhaps this will be a first step toward ending Alaska’s awful distinction as the foster care capital of America. As of 2015, the most recent year for which comparative data are available, Alaska tore apart families at the third highest rate in America – even when rates of child poverty are factored in.  When it comes to the number of children in foster care on any given day, Alaska was number one. Details here: http://bit.ly/2xRaW8f  There is no evidence that Alaska is the child abuse capital of America. The problems cited as reasons for Alaska’s high rate of tearing apart families, are as or more common in other states that take proportionately fewer children.

Nor does Alaska’s obscene rate of removal make children safer. All the time, money and effort spent needlessly removing children, often when family poverty is confused with “neglect,” is stolen from finding children in real danger.
Richard Wexler
Executive Director
National Coalition for Child Protection Reform
www.nccpr.org

Comment: If we can get a 25% reduction in minors initiating nicotine use then there is a good chance they will never smoke. From a Surgeon General's report (last sentence is the most important):

 Among adults who had ever smoked cigarettes daily, the mean age (in years) of smoking initiation was 15.3, and the mean age of beginning to smoke daily was 18.2. Among adults who had ever smoked cigarettes daily, 86.9% had tried their first cigarette by the time they were 18 years of age, while an additional 11.5% did so by 26 years of age. About two-thirds (64.3%) of adults who had ever smoked daily began to do so by 18 years of age, and almost one-third of adults who had ever smoked (22.7%) began to smoke daily between 18–26 years of age. Virtually no initiation of cigarette smoking (<1.5%) and few transitions to daily smoking (<4.3%) actually occurred in adulthood—that is, after 26 years of age.

Comment: A furnace would have to have a catastrophic failure to pump CO into the ducts. The main culprit, as Bob pointed out below is generally CO in the exhaust not going up the vent stack. This is why the "old" style heating systems are inherently more dangerous then the new "high-effiency" ones. The two types are most easily classified as "atmospheric" and "direct vent". Atmospheric takes combustion air from the room it is in so there must be an opening in the stack.  Direct vent takes combustion air from the exterior of the house.  Additionally, all high-e units I know of have a pressure switch that shuts off the system if blockage is detected in the vent stack. So how does the CO enter the house. Hot air rises, so all buildings have a natural stack effect, that is, air is pulled to the highest leakage point. If the natural stack effect exceeds the stack effect of the combustion vent then the fumes will be pulled into the house.

Comment: Bran cereal and some soy products contains fortified B12, which is almost always cyanocobalamin.   Many people have genetic anomalies that prevent proper utilization of this form of B12.

Milk and eggs contain tiny amounts of B12.   If someone has any difficulty absorbing this nutrient, the amount in milk and eggs won't be nearly enough.

Anyone eating this kind of diet should supplement with a high-quality form of B12.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: You're welcome Paul. The old Army didn't pay well, especially for being in harms way. For me, even as a draftee, it was oddly satisfying. As you point out, it invoked a strong sense of "common purpose".

I trained in the South before going over with a mix of educated and uneducated black and white men. We had a sense of common purpose with little social or racial tension . Military service was, for many of us, a right of passage as well as a coming together.

Although some deem it a socialistic endeavor, the Civilian Conservation Corps put 3 million men to work over 10 years with a common purpose. The CCC left a legacy of durable roads, bridges, and buildings across our country. I'd like to see it back.

Comment: In times of austere budgets, it would seem to me that the University of Alaska system would be better served by consolidating certain programs at one school rather than dispersing them throughout their various campuses.  For example, all medical and nursing education is best centralized in Anchorage due to the fact that Anchorages 4 large hospitals provide the settings needed for clinical work.  Similarly, it seems like a geosciences program would be better suited Fairbanks, which has long been the leader in the University of Alaska system in physical sciences.  Rather than jacking up tuition every year, consolidate your programs to the campus where they are best suited and save money on redundant facilities and staff.

Comment: I have known Eric Suchman for almost ten years.  I supervised his student teaching.  I have been inside his classroom at North Eugene High School a number of times and observed him working with students there.  He has supervised student teachers that I have helped to train.  Any attack on Eric's competence or dedication as a teacher of our community's young people is absolutely and totally wrong.  I'm sure that over the course of weeks, many students approached Eric, a teacher whose caring heart permitted them to trust him, to disclose fears they had for the future of their families.  He saw his students in pain, he helped dry their tears, he boldly took a public stand in their defense.  He took a role as someone who could champion their cause and he permitted himself to be exposed to letters like this.

Eric is an excellent teacher who stands up for kids.  Rather than attack him, our community should thank him for his courageous work on behalf of his students.  We need more like him.

This could just as easily be used to describe every Licensed Producer selling cannabis under Health Canada.  Canopy Growth's market cap on TSX is over 1-billion dollars.

Every Licensed Producer in Canada operates under a 'for profit' business model.  NONE operate altruistically, and NONE are non-profit.

Legalization works best if we co-opt our grey-market dispensaries, distributors, and growers into the legal regime, not exclude them.

Comment: Licensing requirements have become largely a barrier to protect the jobs and income of license holders. Look at the construction business. A master plumber is equally qualified to put a new toilet in your house and do the pipe fitting for a nuclear power plant. Likewise a master electrician. Of course neither of them is likely to be doing any actual work on your house. The work will be performed by apprentices making $15/hour (though you will be billed $80/hour) working under the license holder. It has often been suggested that there should be residential licenses for construction trades with much less stringent requirements. Chances of getting that past the current license holders? Zero. The net effect - A few getting rich off the labor of others. And lots of people doing work without permits.

Now that most States and many cities have turned occupational licenses into a massive revenue stream the chances of reform are nil. Welcome to the world of bureaucracy.

Comment: Re: "monotonous and predicable"
I would say both yes and no. From the perspective of "us in the know;" yes, as soon as we see the name Kurgan we can predict what is coming, and some of us might find that monotonous, but that does not include me. On the other, from the perspective of "newbies" who don't know Kurgan's proclivities; no, it is neither predictable nor monotonous. 

I recall fondly being a "newbie" twice, once under the guise of nic and then again as Kurgan, and both times I bit, hook, line and sinker. There is a certain pleasure in being taken in by a master of sarcasm, unless of course one's ego is proud and haughty to the point that being the brunt of a joke is tantamount to torture. 

I do not find Kurgan "monotonous" precisely because it is, arguably, a good thing when the proud and haughty are skewered. 

If "those of us in the know" would shut up about it here, then more "newbies" of the right and left (for both can be proud and haughty) would bite and be skewered.

Strada: I don't know how much of state government employees you actually get to see. I see at least a small part every day. I never saw very much "coddling" and there is less of it now. Those layoffs you want have in many cases already been done by the employees themselves; they quit or retire and are not replaced. I recently looked over my agency organization chart and the number of vacant positions was a of a shock even for me.This state has problems but its not the employees who set policy.

I lean left of centre on social issues, and believe that compassion can be managed fiscally. We have an incredible amount of waste in government, and a lack of accountability when it comes to vanity projects.  

In my City alone we have recklessly spent millions on an  Olympic legacy museum,. and more millions on dubious temporary public art, a one time use floating dock, and a major road re-make for buses which a year later was torn up for rapid transit.  And at the same time we have our women's transition shelter closing and no replacement, and a year long waitlist for language training for refugees/new immigrants. And a dire shortage of seniors and low income housing.

Multiply this example across hundreds of cities, and at the provincial and federal level. Rational, accountable, and just,  fiscal conservatism would provide more money for social compassion.

That is how you can be both.

Comment: Nothing:  The very topic of this story is process.  It is not about "content."  It requires an effective and fair procedure to address issues.  A cumbersome, awkward or unfair process precludes the effective consideration of issues.  If there are a number of specific items on a Council agenda, or a School Board agenda, or a Commissioners agenda, or whatever and wherever, those are the issues  publicly announced to be addressed at the meeting.  

If a public body provides for "public comment on non-agenda items" and two hours are spent listening to persons address anything they feel like addressing, the actual agenda issues will "suffer."  Of course, specific issues may be unique to specific jurisdictions.. That's why they're placed on the agenda.   "Reformatting public input or comparing it to JC won't solve Eugene's problems."  Of course not..  However, it might allow those issues to be addressed in a more efficient and effective manner for the council AND citizens.  Gary Crum

Comment: Hi, James. Thanks for your comment. It was a peaceful gathering. But arrests and confrontations aren't the only danger when very large crowds gather. A number of people were so tightly wedged into confined spaces that there was a very real risk of a stampede if there had been a loud unexpected noise. I heard some people say they had trouble breathing. I've worked in DC for 25 years and covered or participated in every inauguration, as well as the Million Man March, and this seemed more jammed together than any other large event I've covered. I'm aware that it's hard to plan ahead when people assemble in new ways through social networks and it's impossible to predict turnout. I'm sympathetic. But if some people had been hurt, it would have reflected badly on a movement that came together to express their shared humanitarian values.

Comment: Your post pretends this is a race issue, it is not.

It is a financial class issue.

The Canadian government was cruel when it set up its investor immigrant program in the 1980s. It was basically a selfish plan of Canada to vacuum up as many millionaires from Hong Kong as possible. What Canada basically did was to tell poor and middle class folks in Hong Kong, well, tough luck, guys, we do not care that you are about to be taken over by Beijing at the upcoming hand-over. But we will vacuum up as many of your millionaire neighbours there as we can and offer them safety in Canada.

That was unethical, cruel, a mistake.

What Canada SHOULD have done was to set up immigration that accepts the SAME number of people from Hong Kong and China, but from financial strata representative of financial strata of Canadians, not hoarding in millionaires.

If that had been done, Vancouver real estate would not be in its present state, it would be affordable for local workers.

It is not about race.

Comment: A high percentage of those commenting believe the proposed road toll was going to be used for roads. While  some money is needed  for repairs to the Gardiner, most of what Tory was looking for was money for public transit.  If I'm not mistaken, previous governments have increased taxes on gasoline and license registration fees, purportedly to raise money for road repair. Apparently, that money was squandered on other projects. 

Transit users should pay their own way and there should be a significant cost to cyclists for all of the bike lanes, that are used by few at the expense of those who travel  either by car or public transit in terms of  time lost. 

Many of  the residents of the City of Toronto have the privilege of taking public transit or using bike lanes to get to work, but those who can't afford to live in the City are being asked to subsidize those that do, most of whom vote "left" (City Council). It's long past time to have T.O residents pay higher realty taxes.

Comment: I met a Canadian veteran of Kiska on a train in British Columbia.  He talked about the hell that the whole operation was with Canadians and U.S. shooting at each other in the fog.  The troops had inadequate clothing, especially boots for the cold.  There was no beach.  Troops had to be ferried from the ships to the rocky shore.  LST's hadn't been invented yet.  More casualties from cold and wet than combat.  This was the first combining of Canadian and U.S. troops which became the "Devils Brigade" of movie fame.  It was call the First Special Service Force.  The Force was trained at Fort Harrison, Helena, Mt.  The lessons/foulups learned before and on Kiska turned the force into a highly effective unit in the European Theater.  It was the ancestor of the Special Forces Green Berets.

Comment: Hi EN,

I disagree.  I can't sing very well but I can easily sing the "Star Spangled Banner".  The problem with the anthem is not the range or even the lyrics.  The problem is we learn the song by ear as kids.  For the longest time I garbled lyrics (example, donzearlylite) and it takes effort to relearn the song.  No national anthem registers more profoundly than the opening notes of the "Star Spangled Banner" played instrumentally.  Think of the Olympic gold medal presentations as an example.

Yes the the song describes war but it expresses the joy of the nation's survival (the flag being the symbol) and honoring the brave men (now men and women) fighting, some being wounded, and dying in its defense and the then unique concept of individual freedom.

But, you know what?  I am willing to be part of a national process to change the anthem though I seriously doubt I would support a change.  But I have learned over the years one never should say never.

Comment: Good question.  I once knew a Lutheran who was surprised to hear me say I was Catholic first and an American second.  The answer to that question may not be as uniform as you might think.  But despite my being Catholic first, there is no tension (on the issue of immigration) between my being Catholic and being American.  There isn't if you keep certain facts in focus:  1)  These are God's children.  They're entitled to love, compassion, and respect on that ground alone.  2)  # 1 does not entitle them to be here legally.  Every nation --- Christian or non-Christian --- has borders that must be respected.  Short of true necessity, as when a shipwrecked seaman swims to shore on Cape Cod, on land owned by the Kennedy family, aliens have no right to be here without following the rules.  What we have seen is not so much strict necessity as sheer desire.  Lots of people would desire to be on the Kennedy compound.  That bare desire confers no rights.

Comment: It's a complex problem. The patient may no longer be acute, but still require 24/7 care or aren't stable enough to come home, among other reasons. This can also pose a risk of re-admit if they are taken home too early. This is especially true for complex chronic illnesses where the patient has multiple comorbidities. 

If they're going home and the care level is too high, the caregiver risks burnout, the patient risks a readmit, and their caregiver is likely not a doctor who is able to respond any other way but going back to the hospital.

Retirement homes often don't have RNs or those trained enough to handle a patient with complex chronic illness. They are often staffed with one RPN and care is mainly provided by PSWs. 

Long term care has wait lists and many issues.

The family doctor is merely a coordinator to specialists. The patient is above their knowledge. 

There really isn't a place in the system for these patients to go that can care for them other than the hospital.

Comment: The point of it all is that culture differences are the prime factor for separatist feelings. 

Look at Canada: you can split money as much as you want. But you cannot split symbolic things. The major qualms between the ROC and Quebec are all symbolic.  

Alberta can complain all it wants about "equalization" , unfair representation in the HoC or the Senate, but in the end it is unlikely to develop a strong separatist movement because it is too similar to its neighbours. People do not like it? They can move to Manitoba.

Quebec on the other hand is sufficiently distinct to generate a separatist movement irrespective of money. A Quebecker cannot move to Alberta and feel that it is exactly the same country. Language  and laws are different.

Were the Americans poorer than the British when they separated? What was their point?

PS Spain mishandled this in a major way. We are lucky that our Supreme Court acted with sophistication. Neither Chretien nor Parizeau could be trusted.

Comment: It's pretty convenient for all the AGW alarmists to blame every somewhat weather-related event on global warming. Wildfires of immense size have been happening for as long as there have been forests in BC. And you'll note that a large portion of the recent fires are person-caused - which is kind of a stretch for blaming on global warming. 

Also, we've been suppressing natural fires for decades because of our (relatively new) firefighting efforts (and the real need to protect all the houses and infrastructure built in forested areas), which has allowed forest fuels to accumulate. Forest fires are often more intense that they used to be, because the more frequent, lower intensity fires have been suppressed.

I find the most enthusiastic converts to the global warming religion are those that dwell in urban centers, far away from forests and the natural world. They know not of what they speak, and are easily manipulated by the enviro industry.

Comment: Still peddling low-fat Mrs. Beck?

Turkey bacon is just another fake food created to fool people into feeling less guilty about what they eat.

But recently, after the low-fat scam has been exposed, it seems bacon is omnipresent: cooking shows, restaurant menus. People are amazed by delicious healthy dishes they have never tried due to the low fat propaganda.

With the fat content out of the way let's talk about nitrites and nitrates. Nitrates don't cure meat. Nitrites do. Nitrates are added for long term curing. They (more or less) slowly are converted to nitrites by bacteria in meat working like a time release ingredient (initial nitrites in meat will drop gradually). There should be no nitrates in bacon, as it's not a long cure product.

Now about nitrites: they have been found to create cancer causing agents (nitrosamine) when they react with meat protein. This happens under acidic conditions (your stomach) or high temp cooking.

Comment: No offense, but there is a clear difference between immigrants and refugees. Immigrants have been screened according to certain criteria that deems them fit to move to this country since there is a reasonable chance they will contribute and flourish.  The Vietnamese refugees were mainly Hoa i.e ethnic Chinese. They controlled much of the retail trade in Vietnam and many spoke English or French. Same with the Lebanese in the 1970s. The Hungarians were literate, educated and familiar with so-called Western society.

Comment: "Ontario (according all all economic numbers) is booming"
=========

I don't think that is very well supported by facts.

One the plus side Ontario is seeing one of the highest rates of economic growth among Canadian Provinces over the past two or three years, but on the flip side it is lagging behind many neighbouring U.S. states and economic growth is still average-at-best by historical standards.

Further while unemployment has declined nicely in Ontario it has largely been driven by a decline in people looking for work rather than strong job growth.  Some of this is demographics but even taking the aging population out of the calculation Ontario is still seeing people leave the labour force.

Finally wage growth in Ontario has been extremely slow for quite some time now.

There are a few positive economic numbers for Ontario, but a lot of weak numbers as well.

Comment: Spain hasn't had a king for a thousand years, though different parts of Spain had ruling kings and queens and counts. Catalonia became part of one part of Spain (Aragon) when Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Barcelona, was betrothed to Petronilla (Peronella in Catalan),  Queen of Aragon,  in 1137, and thereby becoming Prince of the Aragonese and effective ruler of Aragon, and then passing both Aragon and Barcelona on to their son as the Crown of Aragon.  In effect, Catalonia annexed Aragon. Other parts of Spain had other kings and queens until Charles V became ruler of all the various Spanish kingdoms and counties in 1519. France, interestingly, annexed part of Catalonia (Roussillon) in 1659.  I wouldn't put it past Puigdemont to start demanding that the French hand over Roussillon. That should be interesting.

Comment: China has long sought to build engines durable and reliable enough for the demands of its  modern fourth- and fifth-generation military aircraft, but industrial deficiency and corruption has hampered this project since it began in the late 1980s. The bulk of China’s fighter jets rely on a variant of a Soviet-designed engine, the Saturn AL-31, that is decades old and showing its age. This engine was built for the Su-27 family of Soviet fighters, but China has also used it in its locally-designed J-10 fighter. The J-10 itself is thought to be an adaptation of the cancelled Israeli Lavi. 

The Shenzhou is a larger copy of the Soyuz capsule. The problems with the Long March rocket were resolved thanks to US help. Chinese cars are copies of Japanese, American and European cars

No one questions China's engineering capabilities. I've worked with many Chinese engineers and some are top notch. Perhaps the issue is the environment in place (corruption, groupthink) which may hamper innovation.

Comment: Sorry, but that is untrue in every way.  I do not know a single Na'i Aupuni participant who does not support international human rights, including equality.  I have never heard once, in any discussion among Na'i Aupuni participants, that non-Hawaiians should be "resident non-citizens." In fact, if a NH government is formed and federally recognized, as Z is proposing, the rights of everyone currently living in Hawai'i would be exactly the same.  Hawaiian or not, everyone's voting rights, land rights, and the ability to hold public office, would not change at all.  The State of Hawaii would still operate under the same Constitution and statutes that currently assure those rights are protected. A NH government would only help NH's build consensus among themselves to collectively assert their rights under the UNDRIP, rights that they already have.  Finally, the UNDRIP is clear that the assertion of such rights cannot be at the expense of the rights of other non-indigenous citizens.

Comment: In my mid-century primary school as well, unruly boys were constantly being given "the strap."

In my expensive Catholic private high school, the rooms where the nuns would receive the parents had beautiful architecture and expensive, elegant furniture, but behind the scenes, the actual classrooms, the dormitories and cafeterias and the nun's living quarters were bare-bones and spartan, and the discipline very strict. 

We went from classroom to cafeteria in silent rows and were punished for talking. Our report cards were publicly handed to us and discussed in class, and bad students were humiliated publicly by the Mother Superior. On the last day of school, we were made to get down on our knees to scrub the wood floors. It was supposed to teach us discipline and humility. 

My mother sent me there because her own experience in a similar place was "the best days of my life". I hated it. Some loved it. Different folks like different strokes....

Comment: Dave’s blog gives a misleading picture of the importance that the Bank of Canada attaches to the Canadian housing bubble. The opening statement and the MPR only referenced price growth in the GTA being stimulated by speculation; it made no reference to the Golden Horseshoe. The Teranet-National Bank HPI also shows that besides Toronto (23.0%), Hamilton (19.7%) Victoria (15.9%) and Vancouver (14.3%) had double-digit inflation rates in February. (The March HPI update only was released on the same day as the MPR.)  Arguably, the inflation rate for Vancouver is misleading since prices seem to have peaked there and are now falling, but the same is not true for the other cities. There is also evidence that the housing price inflation in Ontario has spread out beyond not only the GTA, but the Golden Horseshoe to urban centres like Barrie, Guelph and Kitchener-Waterloo.

The overall inflation rate did rise from 2.1% in April to 2.5% in May. The RPI does provide a breakdown. The foreign holidays inflation rate went from 1.0% in April to 2.1% in May while the UK holidays inflation rate went from 7.2% to 6.4%. So foreign holidays contributed to increasing the inflation rate while UK holidays contributed to reducing it, but for reasons unknown the UK holidays inflation rate is still much higher than the foreign holidays inflation rate.

Comment: The basis of the DACA executive order was the president using what he cited as "prosecutorial discretion." This meant that the government would put very low priority on what were described as "Childhood Arrivals". This prosecutorial discretion was DACA policy, but only by executive order. There is no part of the Constitution that says that a President can do something beyond his executive powers because Congress will not act. A challenge was made in federal court in Texas and the EO was found unconstitutional because it went beyond executive powers and altered the immigration statutes by creating an entire class of immigrants entitled to benefits such as work permits. I think Trump sees this as a chance to pressure Congress into coming up with a deal that can trade the DACA program with increased funding for immigration enforcement (including for visa overstayers), as well as important parts of the RAISE act.

Comment: Rolf  - I'm thinking you've been hurt, probably multiple times, by an alcoholic or three. You have my sympathy and understanding. Been there, done that, bought the t-shirt ... and then used it for a tourniquet.

Having a disease doesn't absolve you of the harm you do to others. When you say you have no control over your disease, you obfuscate reality. In the midst of active addiction, you may legitimately say that you have no control. You can't stop without help.

BUT ... once you're sober, you have control over the first drink and the behaviors that lead you up to the first drink. I value what 12-Step groups have done for those in recovery, but people sometimes use the "disease" model to excuse repeated "relapses" that are really just excuses for choosing to take that first drink and then claim a lack of responsibility for every crappy thing that issues from that decision.

Take some responsibility and actually perform Steps 4 thru 10 instead of offering excuses why you can't.

Comment: re the often-repeated claim that renewables are dropping in price and increasing in efficiency:

I wonder, would the Globe publish a letter where I claimed that one plus one is rapidly becoming three and by mid-century it will be four?

That is essentially what renewable energy enthusiasts claim. 

Around five p.m. at this time of year, the sun goes down. Solar power production, already in decline since noon, stops altogether.

And yet, artificial lights all over Ontario -- and elsewhere in most human settlements across the northern hemisphere -- go on.

That phenomenon is a result of engineering. Not solar power, and usually not wind power. And not magic.

The renewables enthusiasts think that the machines that keep Ontario's lights on -- world-class machines that were invented in Ontario, by Ontarians -- are yesterday's machines.

I say, who cares when they were built. They work today. Solar doesn't.

I don't want renewables enthusiasts anywhere near my power system.

Comment: Of course man made climate change exists ... in the urban centers!  With industrialization came urbanization, more paved roads and more buildings that are "heat sinks."  It's a scientifically documented fact that the average temperature in the cities averages about 3-degrees higher than the surrounding countryside, and in some cases 10-degrees higher.  The vast majority of the temperature data is collected in the urban centers, because nobody wants to take a couple of hours to drive out to the country to read a thermometer every day.  In other words, the data is gerrymandered to fit the AGW agenda, but it really has little or nothing to do with CO2.  The rise in CO2 has always followed increases in temperatures by and average of 800 years, and no less than 200 years. It's an effect, not the cause.

If you want a better climate, move out of the city.  The number of hurricanes to hit the US has been consistently between 1 and 3 per year since 1880, with a slight decline in frequency.

Comment: It occurs to me that liberals can be authoritarian, too.
That said, I don't think the US bishops, as a group, were hardliners about HV, especially in the ten years that remained to Paul VI. (JPII changed everything, including the makeup of the hierarchy.) The US Bishops' pastoral letter responding to HV, 'Human Life in Our Day', was a moderate affirmation both of the teaching of HV and of the conscience rights of married couples. There were many priests who wrestled with HV as confessors, and many bishops who tried conscientiously to help them do it. I knew one very conservative priest who left ministry because he thought HV was wrong, but he could see no wiggle room for himself as a confessor. Many people remember or know about Cardinal O'Boyle's confrontation with the Catholic University theologians. I don't think O'Boyle was representative of the US hierarchy. I think it's important to note that he was acting not as Archbishop of Washington but as Chancellor of the University.

Comment: 4) BRETT SEEKS TO JUDGE IDENTITY NOT IDEAS

(comment from previous thread)

Brett: “With real names, we at least know their perspective when they write something, and those people can be held accountable by the community for what they write."

“We” vs “they”. Us vs them. “Those people."

My twist on Brett’s view: “With real names, we at least can make assumptions about their education, culture, religion, race, age, gender, class and worthiness when they write something, and the different kinds of people can be held to different standards by the community for what they write. “

Anonymity fosters equal treatment. That’s why many orchestras now conduct auditions from behind a curtain. The music is what matters, not arbitrary judgements about gender, race, age, ethnicity, religion.

Brett’s word choice suggests little appreciation for how such judgements can increase bias (discrimination or favoritism) in the CB user experience and distract from the exchange of ideas amongst equals.

Comment: I'm sure you were raised to listen to and respect authority.  Most Americans were.   So much so that psychologist Stanley Milgram devised the "Milgrim experiment."   I cannot summarize it sufficiently here, but Milgram was attempting to study the effect of authority figures on ordinary people from all walks of life.   This was in the 60s when the Eichmann trial was international news, and the question of how Nazi Germany could have occurred was questioned by most people in the world.  

Milgram didn't express his conclusions in the exact way I do, but essentially the Milgram experiment proved that 2 out of every 3 people will kill someone they know nothing about just because another person they know nothing about told them to, if the third party appeared to authoritative, i.e., wore a white coat, made notes and directed the experiment. 

I think that experiment is one of the most compelling ever.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

I hope JT has a sense of humour.

Comment: The Civil Rights Act must have been before your time, Charlie.  But it wasn't before mine.  Here are the "facts":

"The Civil Rights Act -- which is best known for barring discrimination in public accommodations -- passed the House on Feb. 10, 1964 by a margin of 290-130. When broken down by party, 61 percent of Democratic lawmakers voted for the bill (152 yeas and 96 nays), and a full 80 percent of the Republican caucus supported it (138 yeas and 34 nays).

When the Senate passed the measure on June 19, 1964, -- nine days after supporters mustered enough votes to end the longest filibuster in Senate history -- the margin was 73-27. Better than two-thirds of Senate Democrats supported the measure on final passage (46 yeas, 21 nays), but an even stronger 82 percent of Republicans supported it (27 yeas, 6 nays)."

In the House, Democrats were nearly 2/3 of the yes votes, but also 2/3 of the no votes.
The filibustering Senators were Democrats.

Comment: The July 2000 issue of the Journal of the American Dental Association reported that “fluoride incorporated during tooth development is insufficient to play a significant role in caries protection.”

Researchers have now overwhelmingly rejected the notion that swallowing fluoride is either necessary or effective for preventing decay. Instead, the current consensus is that fluoride’s benefit (whatever it may be) comes from topical contact with teeth after the teeth have erupted into the mouth. As the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) stated in 1999: “fluoride prevents dental caries predominately after eruption of the tooth into the mouth, and its actions primarily are topical for both adults and children.”

The CDC repeated this position in 2001, affirming that “fluoride’s predominant effect is posteruptive and topical.”

Note the word "topical".

Comment: During Lunar Eclipses, the Earth shows a shadow across the moon. The shadow shows a curvature. Also, the only shape that consistently has a circular shadow, regardless of its orientation, is a sphere. 

If the earth were flat and round, similar to a disk, it could cast a circular shadow, but only for lunar eclipses that occur at midnight. For a lunar eclipse at sunrise or sunset, the earth’s shadow would be an ellipse, a line, or a rectangle, depending upon how thick the disk was compared to its diameter.

The Foucault pendulum is a valid experiment showing Earth's rotation.

Comment: How many times have you seen the following:  One transport pulling out to pass another and taking the next 10 minutes and miles of highway to finally get past.   All this and 1/2 hour later the truck which passed is 15 - 30 seconds ahead of the slower truck.    It's just not worth it.

Concurrent with this should be driver education about lane discipline and yielding (instead of blocking) when a car comes up from behind.    It is not up to drivers to enforce the speed limit.    So if a car is tailgating - just move over and let him/her pass.    Don't be a stubborn jerk and block traffic, which should be ticketable offence.     That will help traffic flow, and if the tailgater is really speeding (or weaving in and out) leave it up to the police to catch them.

Comment: And what pray tell are millennials doing to improve their job prospects themselves? 

My workforce is dominated by millennials and I see many that have an expectation that a university degree gives them a job (or entitles them). I don't hire these individuals. A university degree has never been a sure-fire way to get a job (right now there is a skills shortage in trades). Also, a good lot do not understand to make it to the front office, one often has to start working at the basement.

In all reality, these issues aren't new. Youth unemployment has always been higher than the national average throughout generations. It was hard for me and my peers to get a job 20 years ago and it was hard for  my parents too, however, we all made it.

Many (most) of the millennial generation will make it too, but the ones who expect the PM to create a job for them won't. I wouldn't want that type of person in my employment.

Comment: What you make as a worker and what the costs to the employer  for your unit of work are not equal by any means.   As a worker,  employee,  you get 6.25% of your pay withheld for SSI on the first dollar earned.  And you employer has to match that.  And both pay into unemployment,  Medicare,  and workers compensation insurance.   Suddenly your work unit costs 15% are  more than you make.  Then there are lots of new minimum wage issues,  work day issues,  overtime issues,  and the cost of your unit of labor is more and more,  and you don't produce any more than you did.  Don't expect a raise.  Then required days off,  maternity leave for both parents,  and employers are paying for replacement help,  and keeping your job open for your return.  On and on it goes.   As a result,  not even half the able bodied in America have a job.  It will get worse.  Immigration won't help native born get jobs.  We are a welfare state.  The fight is over benefits to the non working to be paid for by whom?

Comment: Isolated villages exist in Alaska.  When people in those villages need medical, legal, or other professional help or to do simple shopping, they often have to fly from their villages to hub cities like Nome, Bethel, Kenai, Fairbanks, Sitka, or Anchorage.  This is normal Alaskan life.  The same "fly out to a local hub" scenario should hold true for schools which do not need to be located in isolated, high cost, climate threatened villages.  AK DOE could set up regional boarding schools.  This would lower adminstrative, teaching, and school plant costs!  This would greatly improve education opportunities for students and the health of students.  In his essay "Putting a diaper on the Demon", even Jay Hammond wrote about the problems of extending K-12 schools to the wrong locations.

Those dismal village locations which have years long records of low proficiency and high costs should be closed ... for good causes.

Comment: I generally agree but I also see that Eugene's planning and development office has important shortcomings that can impact homeowners. Little or no effort is expended by the city to reduce impacts on adjacent houses. As evidence of this, just take a look at the looming Hyatt Hotel nearing completion at Oakway Center. Substantial light pollution from its parking garage streams onto adjacent neighborhoods. The hotel creates a canyon of darkness during daylight hours. All the while, the entire project is aesthetically deficient. Developers have plopped a hotel onto a parking garage. Greater consideration by the city of Eugene for nearby houses would have resulted in a hotel complex that served the purpose of the developer while also being more suitable to the neighborhood. My advice for the 32nd Avenue and Hilyard residents is to sit down with the developer and assess how perceived impacts can be mitigated through careful design. This essential step did not occur for the Hyatt Hotel.

Comment: I for one am one of the 68% who have a generally favorable attitude toward physician-assisted suicide; and I thought the Sunday NY Times cover story on John Shields and his carefully managed death was well done.

And unlike Phyllis Z., I am not an alarmist, wondering whether civilization is losing its mind. Over this issue at least, no; on others, however, e.g. the embrace of capitalism and competitive economics, yes, but that's another story.

There are two separate moral issues or risks. First, is it immoral for a human being to give up living, no matter his/her circumstances and conditions?, life understood as a gift, or opportunity, or responsibility. Perhaps, but it strikes me as immoral to make that decision for others.

Secondly, if this form of suicide becomes legal, will vulnerable sickly people feel coerced in any way, by family, friends, or medical staff, to choose it? That is a danger; but we are well warned now, and can take reasonable measures to defend against it.

Comment: Another option, when conflict does occur, is to seek assistance from a mediator. Mediation is a voluntary process in which a neutral third party facilitates the negotiations of those involved in the conflict. The parties craft their own solution to the problem that can go beyond what a Court could ultimately decide and the process can bring finality, closure and certainty all at a fraction of the cost of drawn out Court proceedings. Disputes among family members are particularly well suited to mediation given the range and intensity of issues usually involved.

Comment: So you think Quintillion, a for-profit company, has hired Alcatel Lucent and is spending billions on the Arctic Fiber cable to bring internet to a few remote communities on Alaska's west and north coasts? Doubtful.

Arctic Fiber is a way to cut microseconds off of trading algorithms buy and sell times between Japan and European stock exchanges by using the most direct route possible by cutting across the Arctic Ocean. It's financed by banks and big financial trading firms, especially Cooper Investment Partners. Alaska happens to be on the way, and Quintillion in their wisdom have secured federal subsidies to run offshoots from the cable to connect these local communities... it is also good PR to do this, and the cable benefits by power injection at regular intervals as well. But the notion that Arctic Fiber is being installed solely for these communities is laughable.

So my fact-based comments seem asinine to you (meaning "stupid or foolish") -- how do you figure?

Comment: It's great to see ME/CFS (Myalgic Encephalomyalitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome) as we call it in our community, get exposure and more awareness.  It is unfortunate though, that the headline/title of this article isn't accurate.  You may think we're a bit sensitive in pointing this out, and rightly so.  We're not just battling a debilitating disease, we're also battling to get more awareness, more funding for desperately needed research, educating the medical field and so on.  This battle has been going on for several decades, way before I ever became sick with an illness I never heard of.  I believe the majority of us diagnosed with ME/CFS would jump at the opportunity to educate the public with what we know about it.  As others have stated in previous posts that there's over 560,000 Canadians diagnosed with this and this doesn't include those who are still waiting to be diagnosed.  This disease can hit anyone, at any time, children, teens, young adults, middle aged, and elderly.
