Comment: What your comment really demonstrates is a fundamental economic truth:
.
Price is a function of demand, not cost.
.
B.C.'s carbon tax isn't "costing" you, or anybody else, anything.  It is merely shifting wealth from oil companies to the public in the form of public revenue that is either rebated to taxpayers or used to pay for public goods and services.
.
Thus at least a small portion of the negative externalities of the oil industry are being captured in the price, and the public is better off.  All good.
.
That is exactly how it is supposed to work.
.
B.C. would be even better off if it quadrupled the carbon levy, but don't hold your breath on that happening as long as the Oil Party candidate is in office.
.
The fact remains: the sooner B.C. raises that levy, the better off it will be.

Comment: Deserts are spreading and we are losing farmland to it in earth's midband.  Sudan, Somalia, Syria, Iraq etc.   Plants may respond to increases in CO2 but their grain yield does not improve.  Crops need 20" of rainfall/irrigation and without that the CO2 discussion is moot.  Sparse wild plants may well benefit in this regime but they aren't much in the way of food potential.

Global warming is broadening the arid/desert belts further north as the Hadley cells dump their moisture further north.  Hadley cells (rain patterns) will be the next hot topic in the public domain probably.

http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/learning/learn-about-the-weather/how-weather-works/global-circulation-patterns

Cheers,
John Meyer

Comment: I'm not sure that Obama is necessarily responsible, but the U.S. has made HUGE strides in reducing their deficit by, very quietly, undertaking the most stringent austerity measures of any country in the developed world over the past 5 or so years.

While Obama has been writing budget documents Congress, who ultimate controls the budget, has basically tossed everything he wrote in the garbage since the fiscal 2012 budget (this budget went through Congress in early 2011, shortly after the Republics gained control of the House of Representatives with the Democrats still controlling the Senate).

The result?  In fiscal 2011 total expenditures were $3.603T or 23.4% of GDP.  In Fiscal 2016 total expenditures are expected to be somewhere around $3.8T or about 20.2% of GDP, so about a 14% decline in government spending.

Very few countries have done the same thing during the same timeframe.

Comment: I would disagree with this. Law enforcement is their primary duty. Protecting non-involved citizens is next. They signed up to place themselves in harm's way for the greater good. 
That being said, if the committee writing their Rules Of Engagement, don't listen to their concerns and make some effort to address them, then the committee is not doing its job. If the ROE don't make sense, or cannot be applied quickly in a crisis, then they will be ignored. This may lead to excessive force, or to standing down instead of enforcing the law. Both are bad results. And officers should be disciplined, even fired, in both circumstances. An alternative would be to find other employment, straining our already overworked police force. 
It's unfortunate when someone is injured during their interaction with law enforcement, BUT would they have been injured if they had obeyed the law in the first place?What are the costs to society if we allow criminals to ignore the law?

Comment: I owe my mid-life deepening of my faith to a Catholic Navy chaplain who was assigned to my Battalion Landing Team in the Marines. 

We were preparing to attack through the breach in Iraq in March 2003 (within hours..these things today are rarely given actual h-hours...instead it's "be ready within 24 hrs...be ready within 12, be ready within 4."..etc.). We were in our chemical suits, with masks on our hips, in or near our vehicles waiting for the word to move a few Kms to the breach points at the border....Padre walked by and said "who wants to go to Mass"...and I said "I do Father if I can also get a Confession..." and he simply waved me forward to a big hole we had earlier made for our bunker against silkworm missiles in the middle of the Kuwaiti desert.

20 minutes later, Mass was over, Confession was over and I got into my vehicle and went into battle totally serene and totally resolved to "get serious about my faith". 

I got back to the US I wrote to him & thanked him.

Comment: Every major media outlet has Editorial Guidelines posted on their websites. For example the BCC states that in the immediate aftermath of an event involving death, suffering or distress, the use of more graphic material is normally justified to provide a reasonable account of the full horror, although an evocative script is equally important in conveying the reality of tragedy and providing context for the material.  However, as the story unfolds it may become more difficult to justify the continued use of such graphic material.  Then when it comes to considering the story in a contemporary historical context or, for example, marking its anniversary, it may become editorially justified to use the material again.

Something to do with the inherent profit motive demanded by shareholders of corporations?

Comment: OK, let me make it easier  for you to understand, most investments make some sort of a distribution, dividends, interest or capital gain, all mutual funds are able to offset those distributions against the MER, if you held the investment directly you would pay tax, but the mutual fund would write those distributions off against the MER instead of distributing them to you. So to summarize you pay less tax do to less distributions and this in a sense makes your MER lower (or you can look at is as less taxes but the same MER.  I can't make it any easier for you guys to understand, I am quite surprised that most people don't know this, but then again I am not.

Comment: This is what happens when politicians tamper with what should be an open and free marketplace. The ACA and Obama promised coverage for millions more people while reducing price. They then proceeded to require all plans to include coverage for more conditions. They said all of this would still work because of increased efficiency (something our government is so well known for) and greater bargaining power. Clearly, the doctors were going to be on the losing end of this bargain as insurance companies were required to cover more people for more things for less money, and we all know how willing insurance companies are to operate at a loss. The result has been insurance companies dropping out of the ACA market, leaving some areas with as few as one provider (i.e. a monopoly), and doctors dropping out of the market because of low reimbursement rates.

Do we get it now?

It is time to repeal and replace this mess caused by Obama and the Democrats. Support repeal and replacement of the ACA.

Comment: We don't pay taxes directly, but indirectly you do. Hence the trickle down effect. I get money to spend, so I buy an ATV or new car. I pay a license (tax) on that ATV or car. Maybe I put my last several years aside and buy a house. I pay tax on that house. Though this house tax would be paid by someone else, this helps drive the market which causes home values to increase, thus increasing tax income. Or, to go deeper, I spend my PFD, which helps businesses grow, so they re-invest in their own business and pay their business taxes each quarter. Like I said, trickle down. 

To your last comment, the PFD is restricted to residents of the State. Therefore, one could assume that those residents most likely will spend the money here in the state. The difference between the state spending it and the residents spending it is the state does business with big companies, versus the residents spending a higher percentage of it with small companies (restaurants, etc.).

Comment: This bill will (or should) go nowhere - 
Some combination of Seaton’s “income tax with a PFD offset”, plus a minimum PFD per resident cash payout ($500? $750?), but again with a 3-5 year sunset. This might satisfy those wanting the poorest &rural families to feel more financial pain.
This would be a more equitable (less inequitable?) approach that would not devastate our  poorest families, would raise revenues from job-holding rural residents, and would raise revenues from non-residents benefiting from Alaska jobs.  What more could a 21st century Alaska Republican want in the way of others bearing the pain?
Perhaps, in the spirit of "we all sacrifice",  we could also cap PFD cash payments to 4 per family? I'd favor THAT one!
I’d see this as a better stopgap approach - as long as we used the 3-5 year pre-sunset period for a MAJOR PFD revamp, bringing it more in line with Norway & the “sovereign wealth” funds now providing resident and governance benefits in other oil producing nations.

Comment: Equality is about exactly that: Treating everyone equally. That includes those who are perceived to be in positions of power, and those who are perceived to be at the bottom of the ladder. 

Equality is a meaningless concept if the same rules do not apply to both. There can never be equality in any meaningful sense for as long as one set of rules counts for people x and another set of rules counts for people y, because power relations. 

It's a mockery of justice and an indictment of our legal system if this pseudo-intellectualism has crept into our legal corridors. 

And hate speech is clearly defined in our constitution. Saying 'fuck x people' is not hate speech, regardless of which group you substitute for x.

Comment: Canada already exports almost as much lumber to China as it does to the US because someone, finally realized, we can not and should not rely just on the US to buy our products.  Expanding to other parts of Asia is an obvious choice and should have been done years ago. This same situation is playing out today in the oil and gas industry as the feds announce their approval of the Kinder Morgan Pipeline expansion. We've been selling oil to the states, our only customer and getting ripped off for years. It's interesting to note that, the same people who are against free trade and oil and gas pipelines are the same people who demand better social services such as health care, education, daycare, etc!!!...where do they think the "money" is going to come from to pay for those things???
